abstract.p: We argue that region-specific resources are crucial politico-economic factors explaining the success of democratic secessionist movements. Exploiting oil discoveries off the Scottish coast as a natural experiment, we estimate the causal effect of regional resources in a difference-in-differences design with Wales as the counterfactual. Based on constituency-level election results from 1945 to 2001, we show that each additional giant oil discovery has a significant positive effect on the Scottish National Party’s vote share of about 2 percentage points. A triple-differences design using changes in world oil prices as additional exogenous variation supports the causal interpretation of this finding.
